development/how-i-made-this-website/deve.title: Setting Up Your Development Environment
development/how-i-made-this-website/deve.description: Of course, you can't reasonably develop a website without first configuring the tools to do so. As mentioned in the previous section, Ubuntu Server will be used to host the development environment. I write code regularly and host a variety of services on my local network, so I have a physical computer running Ubuntu Server on bare metal, which I use SSH to access. If you would also like to use Ubuntu (not required), you may do the same by following this guide or by creating a virtual instance using the hypervisor of your choice or Multipass. Alternatively, if you don't have access to another computer and cannot/would prefer not to use virtualization for whatever reason, you may use your physical computer.

development/how-i-made-this-website/intr.title: Introduction
development/how-i-made-this-website/intr.description: This tutorial aims to serve as an introduction to hosting a simple personal website using a static site generator (because apparently there aren’t enough of those already). If you like how this website appears and performs, keep reading — all of the steps I followed, from setting up a development environment and registering a domain to pushing my build to Firebase (my web host) are documented in the following few pages.

development/welcome.title: Subsection Header: Development
development/welcome.description: The Development subsection articles on longer, multi-phase projects.

reports/previse.title: HackTheBox — Previse
reports/previse.description: Hello, and thank you for expressing interest in my report on Previse, a CTF hosted by Hack the Box. Previse was uploaded by HTB user m4lwhere 138 days prior to the publication of this report and is currently considered by the HTB community to be easy to intermediate in terms of difficulty.

reports/welcome.title: Subsection Header: Reports
reports/welcome.description: The Reports subsection features personal write-ups on projects I have completed, especially including CTF challenges from competition hosts such as HackTheBox and TryHackMe.

scripts/linux/basic-linux-security-repor.title: Basic Linux Security Report
scripts/linux/basic-linux-security-repor.description: Check on the simple things — for use in competition scenarios. Mirrored on wwucyber.com.

scripts/welcome.title: Subsection Header: Scripts
scripts/welcome.description: The Scripts subsection contains a variety of code snippets I have written or modified, generally for personal use and team-based application during security competitions. Please note that there are also references to and inclusion of the work of others here; if I have not authored code under this section in its entirety, all other contributors are cited appropriately.

welcome.title: Welcome!
welcome.description: The Documents section hosts a growing number of technical articles, focused primarily on cybersecurity challenges (HackTheBox, TryHackMe, etc.) and miscellaneous development projects. While relatively sparse now, I intend to share much of my interesting activity here. If nothing immediately sparks your interest, please check back soon. The left-hand sidebar can be used to navigate between the pages of this section.
